*p**location_mentioned*Potosi Missouri*/location_mentioned* *date_mentioned n="03-21-1830">Sunday [Mch 21st 1830]*/date_mentioned**/p* *p*1/2 after 9 o'clock *person_mentioned*J. F. Perry */person_mentioned*started on a visit or rather for the purpose of viewing*location_mentioned* Austins Colony*/location_mentioned* in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, arrived at *location_mentioned*Hercu- lanium*/location_mentioned* on the *date_mentioned n="03-21-1830.">same evening*/date_mentioned* there I had to remain the *date_mentioned n="03-22-1830">22d */date_mentioned*and *date_mentioned n="03-23-1830">23rd*/date_mentioned* waiting for the steam Boat North America for a passage to *location_mentioned*New Orleans.*/location_mentioned* Met *person_mentioned*James A. Austin*/person_mentioned* who starts in company with me with a view to settle himself in *person_mentioned*Texas*/person_mentioned*, the S. B. N america ari'd the eving of the *date_mentioned n="03-23-1830">23d */date_mentioned*during my stay here the S. B *person_mentioned*Diana */person_mentioned*passed down for *location_mentioned*Louisvill */location_mentioned*Three Steam Boats passed up *date_mentioned n="03-24-1830">24th */date_mentioned*wednesday, arrived at the *location_mentioned*cliff of Selma*/location_mentioned* here we remain'd taking in Lead untill *date_mentioned n="03-25-1830">25th */date_mentioned*thirsday 12 o'clock started about 12 o'clock passed the S. B.——— for *location_mentioned*St Louis*/location_mentioned**/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="03-31-1830">March 31st Wednesday*/date_mentioned* Land at *location_mentioned*New Orleans*/location_mentioned* about 1/2 past 2 o'clock P M. remained in *location_mentioned*New Orleans*/location_mentioned* untill *date_mentioned n="04-9-1830">friday the 10th day of April*/date_mentioned* at 12 oclock saild *location_mentioned*in the Schooner Pocahontas*/location_mentioned* for the*location_mentioned* port of Brazoria*/location_mentioned* in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, *person_mentioned*Capt Carpenter*/person_mentioned* master with 12 *person_mentioned*Cabin pasengers*/person_mentioned* viz *person_mentioned*Mr Mills*/person_mentioned* and*person_mentioned* Brother Mr Grason*/person_mentioned* *person_mentioned*Mr Dawson*/person_mentioned* *person_mentioned*Mr Jameson.*/person_mentioned* *person_mentioned*M Brown */person_mentioned**person_mentioned*Mr. Jones*/person_mentioned* and *person_mentioned*Mr Lefwick */person_mentioned*of *location_mentioned*virga */location_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*Syghts */person_mentioned*from *location_mentioned*New Yourk*/location_mentioned**/p*
*p**person_mentioned*James A Austin*/person_mentioned* and myself and about 25 or 80 deck *person_mentioned*pasengers*/person_mentioned* among home [whom] are a nomber of *person_mentioned*weomen */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*children */person_mentioned*among them was *person_mentioned*Majr Brygs*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="04-09-1830">friday night*/date_mentioned* from 8 oclock in the morning lay at anker until morning *location_mentioned*7 or 8 miles above the S. W Pass of the Mississippi*/location_mentioned**/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="04-10-1830">Saturday morning 11th*/date_mentioned* histed sail about 8 oclk am took in the *person_mentioned*Pilot */person_mentioned*a few miles above the bar. got to sea and discharged the *person_mentioned*Pilot*/person_mentioned* lay to anker *location_mentioned*for [four] or five miles S. W of the bar*/location_mentioned* for want of wind until*/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="04-11-1830">Sunday Morning 12th*/date_mentioned* histed sail under a light wind*/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="04-13-1830">Tuesday morning*/date_mentioned* about 9 or 10 oclk *location_mentioned*in sight of Galveston Island */location_mentioned*said to be 45 miles long on which stands only 3 solitary Live oak at some distance apart I suppose Judging from the distance we was from them that they must stand *location_mentioned*one or two miles apart*/location_mentioned* came too oft the*location_mentioned* month of the Brazoses*/location_mentioned* in the evening there not being water to carry us over the bar lay at ancker untill *date_mentioned n="04-14-1830">Wednesday Morning 15th*/date_mentioned* I with a nomber *person_mentioned*passengers */person_mentioned*went on shore in the Boat to *person_mentioned*Mr. Micheles */person_mentioned*who lives emediately at the*location_mentioned* mouth of the Brazoes L 28° 57' Longetuted*/location_mentioned**person_mentioned* Mr Mitchel*/person_mentioned* has a small *location_mentioned*salt works*/location_mentioned* in opperation from which he makes from 8 to 10 bushel pr day worth at the works $1.00*/p*
*p*60 Gal. water make 1 bushel all *location_mentioned*along the sea coast is prairia and salt marches for two or thr[ee] miles back*/location_mentioned* when the appearance of fine timber, the soil on the *location_mentioned*Prarie */location_mentioned*is sand except in the *location_mentioned*salt Marches*/location_mentioned*, which is clay, the land appears to be level as far as can be seen back (*person_mentioned*Michel */person_mentioned*makes use of drift wood entirely for to make salt of which there is a great abundance but up *location_mentioned*along the coast*/location_mentioned* and more particularly *location_mentioned*near the mouth of the Brazos*/location_mentioned* nothing can be raised near the *location_mentioned*sea cost*/location_mentioned* that groes high in concequence of the heavy winds off sea good Brick can be made anywhere on the *location_mentioned*sea board*/location_mentioned*. *person_mentioned*Mr. Michals */person_mentioned*chemney is built with very good Brick made *location_mentioned*close to his hous*/location_mentioned*—the cattle appears to be in fine order and the place healthy*/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="04-14-1830">Wednesday 15th*/date_mentioned* the vessel got *location_mentioned*over the bar*/location_mentioned* after much dificulty she struck verry hard on it and the wind beat her back *location_mentioned*into a bason formed by the bar*/location_mentioned* and a bar which puts out from *location_mentioned*West side of the brases emideately at the mouth*/location_mentioned* but with two or three hours hard work she was got into the *location_mentioned*Brasos */location_mentioned*where we lay until *date_mentioned n="04-15-1830">thirsday morning*/date_mentioned* saild and warped up the *location_mentioned*Brasos*/location_mentioned*, This day about 15 or 16 miles *date_mentioned n="04-16-1830">Friday morning 16th*/date_mentioned*. myself and 4 others left the vessel in the boat and arrived at *location_mentioned*Brasoria */location_mentioned*at 2 oclock P. M. I went in compy with *person_mentioned*Sayer*/person_mentioned*. to *location_mentioned**person_mentioned*Josiah H Bell*/person_mentioned*s*/location_mentioned* *location_mentioned*12 miles north on the San Felepe road */location_mentioned*that evening next morning *date_mentioned n="04-17-1830">Saturday 17th */date_mentioned*returned to *location_mentioned*Brazoria */location_mentioned*and found the vessel had arrivd returnd to *location_mentioned**person_mentioned*Mr. Bell*/person_mentioned*s*/location_mentioned*, *date_mentioned n="04-18-1830">18 Sunday */date_mentioned* returned to *location_mentioned*Brazoria */location_mentioned*for *person_mentioned*James Austin*/person_mentioned* to [ok] him to *person_mentioned*squir Bell*/person_mentioned*s then left, borrowed a mule from *person_mentioned*squire Bell,*/person_mentioned* and continued on at 4 oclock P M. in company with a *person_mentioned*Mr Anderson*/person_mentioned* to se *person_mentioned*Col Austin*/person_mentioned* who we heard was in the *location_mentioned*neighbourhood of Harrisburg*/location_mentioned*. cross the *location_mentioned*brasos */location_mentioned*that evening *location_mentioned*12 miles from *person_mentioned*Bell*/person_mentioned*s in a N E. direction*/location_mentioned* at what is call'd *location_mentioned*Boliver*/location_mentioned* where a *location_mentioned*Town */location_mentioned*had been Laid out and abandoned. *person_mentioned*Mr Warren Hall */person_mentioned*was at this place where we remaind for the night was very politely treated by *person_mentioned*Mr Hall */person_mentioned*continued our course in the morning *location_mentioned*6 miles through the Brasos Bottom*/location_mentioned* which very heavy timbered and great quantities of cain growing on it to *person_mentioned*Mr Hodges*/person_mentioned* where we took Breakfast it rained considerable this morning here we met with *person_mentioned*Wm Harris Esqr*/person_mentioned* who informed us*person_mentioned* col Austin*/person_mentioned* was on*location_mentioned* Galveston Bay */location_mentioned*or *location_mentioned*Dickersons Bayou*/location_mentioned* as he had left him the *date_mentioned n="04-17-1830">day before*/date_mentioned* on *location_mentioned*Clear Creek about 25 Miles distant*/location_mentioned*, and agreed to get a *person_mentioned*hand */person_mentioned*or pilot us himself if we would wait untill *date_mentioned n="04-20-1830">Tuesday'morning*/date_mentioned* which we did remain at*person_mentioned* Mr Harris */person_mentioned*and about 1/2 mile from where we breafasted where we was verry friendly treated *date_mentioned n="04-20-1830">Tuesday Morning*/date_mentioned* Started in compy with a *person_mentioned*Mr Boatright*/person_mentioned* crossed the head water of *location_mentioned*Chocolate Bayou*/location_mentioned* *location_mentioned*Halls creek */location_mentioned**location_mentioned*dickersons Bayou*/location_mentioned* and *location_mentioned*Cleare Creek*/location_mentioned* recrossed *location_mentioned*Clear Creek*/location_mentioned* and camped on *location_mentioned*Dickesons Bayou */location_mentioned**date_mentioned n="04-21-1830">wednessday morning 21st*/date_mentioned* continued a East course and struck—*location_mentioned*Galveston Bay*/location_mentioned* at *location_mentioned*davises Point*/location_mentioned* at bout 9 oclock A M where we found *person_mentioned*Col. Austin*/person_mentioned* just ready to start with the *person_mentioned*Surveyors */person_mentioned*who we [re] meandering the *location_mentioned*bay coast */location_mentioned*and *location_mentioned*Dickesons Bayou*/location_mentioned* *person_mentioned*Mr Anderson*/person_mentioned* Started from this place for *location_mentioned*St. Felepe*/location_mentioned* by the way of *location_mentioned*Harrisbourg*/location_mentioned*. I remained with *person_mentioned*Col Austin */person_mentioned*and the *person_mentioned*Surveyors*/person_mentioned* untill *date_mentioned n="05-02-1830">Sunday morning 1st May*/date_mentioned* when *person_mentioned*Col. A.*/person_mentioned* and myself left the *person_mentioned*surveyors */person_mentioned*for *location_mentioned*Harrison on the brasos*/location_mentioned* got to *person_mentioned*Mr. Hall*/person_mentioned* that night who lives just *location_mentioned*at the Timber of the Brasos Bottom at the edge of the Prararie */location_mentioned**date_mentioned n="05-03-1830">Monday May 2d*/date_mentioned* left *person_mentioned*Col A */person_mentioned*at *person_mentioned*Squire Harris*/person_mentioned* he remained here to get some provisions for the *person_mentioned*surveyors */person_mentioned*and was to met them *location_mentioned*at the mouth of Pleasent creek on Chocolate Bayou*/location_mentioned* and agreed to meet me in *location_mentioned*San Felipe*/location_mentioned* on *date_mentioned n="05-10-1830">Monday 9th May.*/date_mentioned* I returned to *location_mentioned**person_mentioned*Mr. Bell*/person_mentioned*s*/location_mentioned* to see *person_mentioned*James Austin*/person_mentioned* and found him geting some better but still in a verry delecate and doutfull state of health *person_mentioned*Mr. Bell*/person_mentioned* taking particular and motherly care of him and if he can be restored attention and good nursing he must recover under his care, remained here two days and a half—and then left in comy. with *person_mentioned*Squire Bell */person_mentioned*on *date_mentioned n="05-07-1830">fridy the 7*/date_mentioned* for *location_mentioned*San Philipe de Austin*/location_mentioned*, arrived at *location_mentioned*san Felepe Satarday*/location_mentioned* the *date_mentioned n="05-08-1830">8th*/date_mentioned* after dark. *location_mentioned*San Philepe*/location_mentioned* is verry pleasently situated on the *location_mentioned*W. side of the Brasoses 85 miles from the mouth on a high praria*/location_mentioned*—the prararia comes to the *location_mentioned*river */location_mentioned*at this place and the *location_mentioned*Bank on the side the Town is situated is much higher than any I have saw on the river*/location_mentioned* it [is) said it is 61 or 60 feet high there is perhaps------*person_mentioned*famalies */person_mentioned*residing in it among which there is 3 *location_mentioned*Taverns*/location_mentioned* 7 or 8 *location_mentioned*Trading establishments*/location_mentioned* *location_mentioned*grog shops*/location_mentioned* and *location_mentioned*Stores */location_mentioned*one *location_mentioned*Black smith shop*/location_mentioned* one *location_mentioned*printing office*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*The country from the *location_mentioned*mouth of the Brasos*/location_mentioned* for five or six Miles is all a *location_mentioned*prararia */location_mentioned*near the *location_mentioned*sea shore*/location_mentioned* sandy then low and marchey. gradually rises a little untill the timber commences is generaly a clay land, and looks poor much appearences of Craw fish, although the land looks unproductive, there is emence coats of fine Grass growing on it and affords emence pasturage for Stock of all kind, from where the Timber commences *location_mentioned*on the Brasos */location_mentioned*the *location_mentioned*Bottom of the Brassos*/location_mentioned* are heavely timbered as far up as I have yet been say from *location_mentioned*one to six and eight miles on each side of the river*/location_mentioned* and in some places wider the timber consists of live oak Large quantities of it Black- oak Bed oak post oak white oak pecan Ash mulberry Ellam cottonwood and sundry other not recollected the undergroth is wild peach sasafras*/p*
